Description: Egyptian terracotta figure head fragment wearing hood. Probably from a Persian Rider. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of red paint on face. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with black core, with abundant quartz, mica, organic vesicles and white inclusions.Very worn.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Very worn example. Probably locally produced at the Naukratis Terracottas workshop that was operational from around the 3rd to 2nd century BC. Parallel from Bubastis (Perdrizet 1921, pl. 13:47) and similar to example from Chatby cemetery, Alexandria (Adriani 1956, 36, fig. 36, no.25810), thought to be of Alexandrian production. An unprovenanced Egyptian parallel was given a late 4th century BC date by Fischer (Fischer 1994, pl. 6, no.39). For the muffling and the gesture, compare a ‘dancer’ from Alexandria, dated to the beginning of the 3rd century BC (Besques 1992, pl. 75a). Parallels from Naukratis in British Museum (GR 1886,0401.1447, Bailey 2008, no. 3516), Bristol Museum (H2221) and similar fragments also in Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology (NA545). Good parallels from Athribis (Tell Atrib) dated to the 3rd and 2nd century BC (Szmańska 2005, nos. 209 and 210). Adriani, A. 1956.
